Award.AwardTitle: Investigating Human Coastal Migration Through Exploration of a Paleolithic Site

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The fundamental goal of this project is to gain insight into how humans spread from an originally limited region within Africa to a worldwide distribution which includes all continents. Understanding how this process - especially in its earliest stages - took place has the potential to shed light on basic human adaptations.

With National Science Foundation support, Dr. Amanuel Beyin and an international team of colleagues from the US and the Sudan will conduct one season of high-risk archaeological exploration along the Sudanese Red Sea coast (northeast Africa) to locate prehistoric sites associated with early human use of coastal resources and dispersal events out of Africa. There is an emerging anthropological consensus on the first appearance of early modern humans in Africa around 200,000 years ago, and their subsequent dispersals to Europe and Asia. However, there is disagreement about the specific routes along which early humans dispersed out of Africa (e.g. the Sinai Peninsula vs the Bab al Mandab strait). The possibility of early humans using coastal landscapes as potential dispersal conduits during their migration out of Africa and beyond is receiving increasing support among researchers in recent years. As a region featuring a long and heterogeneous coastal strip, the proposed study area in the Sudanese Red Sea zone represents a vital region for assessing current hypotheses concerning early human coastal migration out of Africa. The proposed high-risk archaeological exploration will test the hypothesis that the Red Sea basin served as a viable refugium and dispersal corridor for early humans.

The nature of the research at this stage requires finding paleoanthropological sites, and describing their geological settings and archaeological contents (such as types of artifacts and fossils and their distribution patterns). To achieve these goals, the proposed research will employ vehicle-assisted pedestrian surveys (field team walking along established transects), recording artifact and fossil concentrations with a GPS, and test excavations at selected stratified sites. Field data compiled during this pilot survey will be entered into a Geographic Information System database specifically designed to accommodate site proveniences, artifact/fossil density, locations of important environmental features (river channels, shorelines and stable plateau) and lithic raw material locations. The results of this pilot work will enable us to pursue a long-term, interdisciplinary fieldwork in this important region.

The intellectual merits of this high-risk exploration are that, by documenting new prehistoric coastal sites from a less explored part of the Red Sea basin, the research will generate fresh archaeological data with which to clarify: a) the role that the African side of the Red Sea basin played in human adaptations, survival and dispersals out of Africa, b) possible demographic and cultural connections among hominid groups who occupied northeastern Africa, the Arabian Peninsula and Southwest Asia and, c) compare the nature of prehistoric human adaption there with neighboring regions. In a wider geographic context, this research will contribute to global theoretical debates surrounding the geographic contexts of early human dispersals out of Africa and the role of coastal habitats in stimulating hominid evolution, adaptations and dispersals.

The broader impact of the project is that, it will contribute to advancing greater international paleoanthropological research collaboration among researchers - including two ethnic minorities in the discipline - from two US institutions and two Sudanese universities. In the future, it will provide diverse research opportunities for students from both American and African institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With a grant from the National Science Foundation, Dr. Amanuel Beyin (University of Louisville) recently led an international team of researchers from Sudan and India to conduct a high-risk archaeological exploration in the western periphery of the Red Sea, East Africa. The study area encompasses the Agig and Khor Baraka districts in the Red Sea coastal region of Sudan. Despite its pivotal geographic location linking the fossil-rich East African Rift region with Southwest Asia, the western coastal strip of the Red Sea had seen little archaeological research in the past. The launching of this pioneering project was thus aimed at finding Stone Age sites that can inform us about the nature of hominin settlement history in the region. The recovered evidence will be subsequently used to assess the role of the region in hominin dispersal out of Africa.

Two seasons of survey documented six new Stone Age sites and numerous low-density artifact find-spots in diverse landscape settings in the study area. The most conspicuous artifact class at the documented sites are what archaeologists call handaxes that are characteristic of the Acheulean technocomplex. Other recorded artifact types include points, scrapers, and prepared core products referable to the Middle Stone Age. Most of the discovered sites lie inland (outside of the coastal zone) signifying that the inhabitants relied on terrestrial resources. The absence of sites in the coastal zone can be interpreted as suggesting either sites were lost to shoreline erosion or that hominins had not yet developed suitable behavioral strategies for exploiting the coastal niche. The discovery of stone tools characteristic of the Acheulean and Middle Stone Age technocomplexes clearly attests that the region hosted multiple human occupation episodes. It is also worth noting that the Acheulean and Middle Stone Age occurrences maintain close resemblance to finds in the interior eastern African sites, implying cultural and demographic connections between hominin groups that once inhabited the Red Sea coast and the interior habitats.

The intellectual merits of the project are that, firstly it has revealed archaeological evidence that was previously unknown to the paleoanthropological community. This is the first team to survey in the Sudanese Red Sea coastal region and discover new Stone Age sites that indicate that the western periphery of the Red Sea hosted multiple hominin occupation episodes. Based on the discovered evidence, it is reasonable to speculate that the Red Sea coast was a key early dispersal corridor- and possibly the first. Secondly, the paleoanthropological community will benefit directly by being able to utilize our data for global and intra-regional comparative interpretations of hominin behavior. Overall, the project serves as a foundational step toward bringing the Red Sea region into the spotlight of human evolutionary research, thus leading to gaining new insights into hominin lifeways and dispersals scenarios out of Africa. The results of our fieldwork have been published in two peer-reviewed journals, namely Journal of Field Archaeology (2019) and Evolutionary Anthropology (2017), and presented at two international conferences in the US and Morocco, namely Paleoanthropology Society and Pan-African Archaeological Congress.

In terms of its broader impact, the project has offered a valuable opportunity for research collaboration among three early-career archaeologists from the US, India and the Sudan, all from underrepresented minority groups in paleoanthropological research. Moreover, staff of the National Corporation for Antiquities and Museums of Sudan, and students from the University AlNilain in Khartoum gained training in archaeological survey. The project has also offered employment opportunity to 11 Sudanese citizens.
